content.question: A parallel-plate capacitor is connected to a power supply with potential difference <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Î”</mi><mi>V</mi></math>. The area of the plates of the capacitor is doubled while the potential difference of the power supply is halved. A student claims that the charge stored on the capacitor must have increased. Is the claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the electric potential decreased.
No, because the distance between the plates remains the same.
No, because the capacitance and electric potential difference both changed.

content.answer: No, because the capacitance and electric potential difference both changed.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
